ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a much deeper knowledge of Assyria and its history by taking this course. I had considered myself to be knowledgeable about this topic before taking this course, but I was unaware about the sheer amount of detailed data that exists on the subject.

I learned an immense amount about the Assyrian Empire and the historical process of how we learned more about them. We learned a significant amount about the different types of evidence from textual to archaeological. It was really great to fill in this gap in my historical knowledge.
Super cool class!
I gained much knowledge about the Assyrian empire and I further developed primary source analysis skills
I learned a lot about Assyria  Prof Frahm manages to introduce you to a subject that is expansive in a way that is not daunting.
A good introduction to the general history of the Assyrian empire and some of its most important characters. Practice in interpreting ancient primary sources in translation.

Critical assessment of historical data
Breath of background knowledge of the Ancient near east 
Good bibliography for future work

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked how the students were invited to participate in debates about unknown points in Assyrian history (i.e., who killed Sennacherib?). I liked the interdisciplinary aspect of the course as well, engaging in both archaeology and biblical studies in addition to its main focus on Assyriology. I liked how we were invited to present on the readings throughout the course. I honestly don't think the class had any real weaknesses.

I found the material and the readings really interesting. It was a period for which I only had a cursory knowledge so each class felt like brand new material. We also had to chance to jump in and ask questions during the mini-lectures so it was easy to stay engaged. Sometimes we got a little side-tracked on tangents that were still interesting, but we occasionally had to rush through some of the bigger moments.

The professor is very knowledgeable and can often just speak from memory about complicated matters, this does lead to the class straying slightly from the plan set by the syllabi, which is not always a bad thing! This does mean that the scheduled reading was revised quit frequently which prevented getting ahead
I think there could be more small assignments so not everything is based on the midterm and final.

The course is very well-organized and does a good job covering a large period of time. The workload is very manageable. There is always some difficulty in a class that is heavily primary source-based when the texts are all in translation, but that can't be helped because most students obviously don't know Akkadian. However, I would have liked to see a little more visual material culture incorporated into the class rather than so many texts. There was a good balance of lecture and discussion during class time. The visit to the Babylonian collection was a lot of fun, and it helps with engagement if you have held tablets in your hand and tried writing in cuneiform. I have to say, some of the time spent on the Bible seemed unnecessary, and instead I would like to have spent more time on the middle stages of the Assyrian empire and the magnates.
It was very well organized and hand excellent reading material. Only wish we had more discussion than lecture

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in the ancient Near East, or history in general, for that matter.

I would recommend this course if you are at all interested about the Ancient Near East. Professor Frahm has an encyclopedic knowledge and the material is quite interesting. The class size isn't too large and the workload is exceedingly manageable making it a great extra class to fit into your schedule to learn about something totally new.
yes!
Yes! Anyone who wants to know about this time period, or wants to get involved with the department should take a course with Frahm
Yes  especially if you are interested in ancient history.

It may appear to be a niche topic, but the Assyrians were very influential despite their lack of fame today relative to the Romans, Egyptians, etc. Worth taking if you are interested in ancient history, archaeology, or even biblical studies. Professor Frahm really is an authority on the topic and makes the material feel very relevant and easy to understand. The history of the Assyrians, especially the Sargonid kings who are covered at the end of the class, is particularly exciting in a narrative sense. There are enough assassinations, coups d'etat, and general intrigue to keep it interesting.
Yes
